column2: THE LEADER OF AMERICA'S BIGGEST ARMY

column2: It was a historic moment, on that June day, in the third year of the World War.
column3: It was a historic moment, on that June day, in the third year of the World War.

column2: On the landing stage at the French harbor of Boulogne was drawn up a company of French soldiers, who looked eagerly at the approaching steamer.
column3: On the landing stage at the French harbor of Boulogne was drawn up a company of French soldiers, who looked eagerly at the approaching steamer.

column2: They were not dress parade soldiers nor smart cadets--only battle-scarred veterans home from the trenches, with the tired look of war in their eyes.
column3: They were not dress parade soldiers nor smart cadets-only battle scarred veterans home from the trenches, with the tired look of war in their eyes.

column2: For three years they had been hoping and praying that the Americans would come--and here they were at last!
column3: For three years they had been hoping and praying that the Americans would come-and here they were at last!

column2: As the steamer slowly approached the dock, a small group of officers might be discerned, looking as eagerly landward as the men on shore had sought them out.
column3: As the steamer slowly approached the dock, a small group of officers might be discerned, looking as eagerly landward as the men on shore had sought them out.

column2: In the center of this group stood a man in the uniform of a General in the United States Army.
column3: In the center of this group stood a man in the uniform of a General in the United States Army.

column2: There was, however, little to distinguish his dress from that of his staff, except the marks of rank on his collar, and the service ribbons across his breast. To those who could read the insignia, they spelled many days of arduous duty in places far removed.

column2: America was sending a seasoned soldier, one tried out as by fire.
column3: America was sending a seasoned soldier, one tried out as by fire.

column2: But his dark eyes glowed with the untamable fire of youth.
column3: But his dark eyes glowed with the untamable fire of youth.

column3: He was full six feet in height, straight, broad shouldered, and muscular.

column3: The alert poise of the man showed a nature constantly on guard against surprise-the typical soldier in action.

column2: Such was General Pershing when he set foot on foreign shore at the head of an American army--the first time in history that our soldiers had ever served on European soil.
column3: Such was General Pershing when he set foot on foreign shore at the head of an American army-the first time in history that our soldiers had ever served on European soil.

column2: Who was this man who had been selected for so important a task?

column3: His was a task of tremendous difficulties, and a single slip on his part would have brought shame upon his country, no less than upon himself.

column2: That he was to succeed, and to win the official thanks of Congress are now matters of history.
column3: That he was to succeed, and to win the official thanks of Congress are now matters of history.

column2: The story of his wonderful campaign against the best that Germany could send against him is also an oft-told story. But the rise of the man himself to such commanding position is a tale not so familiar, yet none the less interesting.

column3: Their honeymoon was spent among the hardships of a construction camp in Missouri; and here at Laclede, in a very primitive house, john Joseph Pershing was born, september thirteenth eighteen sixty.
